content.description: A contender for the best moderate boulder at Sundown (maybe the best problem overall), and yeah, it is a sloper traverse. Start at the bottom of the lip on a sloper, doing a campus a move or two left, then throw a heel. You know what to do for the rest, though your forearms might be blown to hell faster than the Australians at Gallipoli. Top out at the pointy tip of the boulder in whatever way suits you best.Beautiful.
content.protection: pads, we used 4, but 3 could be fine.
content.location: On the Campfire Boulder, the big lip facing the trail, to the right of Tourist Trap. It's THE LINE.

content.description: Start with your right hand on a small undercling and your left hand on the obvious incut edge.  Match and throw to the sharp edge/flake.  Match (or don't) and throw big to the lip and top out.  Be ready to answer a lot of questions from tourists hiking on the trail.  You've been warned!
content.location: This problem is located on a large faced boulder on the right side of the hiking trail.  It is identifiable by a large black streak from an old campfire.

content.description:
I did a stand-start, but a lower start or a sit-start could make this one substantially harder. It iss barely less than vertical and is pretty sustained slab climbing the whole way up. It is a little tall, but has a great landing.

 NOTE: This boulder and the "Stop in French" boulder are adjacent to each other. R Hall NH Admin 7/17/20
content.location:
Revised (7/17/20) Location Directions: Direct Approach to "Stop in French" & Tall Boy Boulders - Continue on the hiking trail to the split, take the "straight ahead" branch (i.e. don't go left ) and continue about 250 ft.  Look for a place where the trail levels off after a gentle rise and there are two reasonably large (4-5 ft high) boulders on the left and a group of 4 large pine trees on the right.  (photo) ...look to your right and the "Tall Boy"  boulder should be visible about 100 ft through the open trees. 

Original Directions: Walk down the boulder loop trail, passing the first group of boulders. Walk on the trail until you find the boulder I called Lurp. Then turn right into the woods. This large boulder should be clearly visible about 50 yards into the woods.

content.description: Lie down underneath the overhanging prow of Stop in French, pull on using full body compression, and grunt your way up the arete into the stand start. Turning the lip is as ugly feeling as the stand start is classy.The sit start's crux favors shorter climbers, but the stand start's crux favors the tall.
content.location: Crawl under Stop in French to find the start holds.

content.description: Start on a left hand crimp and the arete. Move up the arete to reach jugs. Top out.
content.location:
Right next to Tallboy.

Revised (7/17/20) Direct Approach to "Stop in French" & Tall Boy Boulders - Continue on the hiking trail to the split, take the "straight ahead" branch (i.e. don't go left ) and continue about 250 ft.  Look for a place where the trail levels off after a gentle rise and there are two reasonably large (4-5 ft high) boulders on the left and a group of 4 large pine trees on the right.  (photo) ...look to your right and the "Tall Boy"  boulder should be visible about 100 ft through the open trees.

content.description: Start matched on a rail with your feet out left. Work your way up and right to top out.A fun short problem!
content.location: Walk on the trail until you see a big, blank, overhanging boulder on the right covered in ash. Turn right off the trail and you'll see a bunch of smallish boulders.  This boulder to to your left separated a little from the other boulders.

content.description:
This climb is almost a joke, but I thought it was fun enough to warrant its own page.   

  Stand up on the slab and jump to the top.
content.location: Right next to Ledge Fund.

content.description: The bigger badder version of Princess Bunnyrabbit. Start matched on the crimp for Tourist Trap. Make a big and really difficult move to the starting sloper of Princess Bunnyrabbit, then finish out that problem. Then tell all your homies you just sent the Queen Bunny variation to Princess Bunnyrabbit.
content.location: Start as per Tourist Trap, but go straight to the lip and traverse up.

content.description: Stand start matched on an obvious sloper just above the crimp that starts Tourist Trap. Slap your way out right on bad holds with tricky feet and body tension to top out at the pointy tip of the boulder. Wow, so hard. I can't believe its called Princess Bunnyrabbit.
content.location: Start at the best spot in the lip above the tourist trap crimp.

content.description: Start on two good crimps while ignoring the big sloper (unless you want to use it). Pull pon with high feet into the two crimps straight above then move up and right to the lip to top out.
content.location: Walk to the left of the Landmark Boulder, this will be straight ahead of you to the right of the gap you walk through to find Ledge Fund and Slab Dyno.

content.description: Sit start on the right side of the boulder using a small left side pull and right hand on a sloper.  Work your hands up the arete, and figure out how to make the large move to the side pull on the featured face.  Once you're stretched out, slap up to the top of the boulder and top out.
content.location: This route is located on the campsite warmup boulder which is to the right from the Stop in French boulder and is located downhill towards the campsite. Bob Hall Description: Boulder is about 100 +/- feet southwest* of "Tall Boy" / "Stop in French" boulders. ( * i.e. back in the direction of the parking lot, but  roughly, with a 45-degree angle towards the campground.) Or, see the directions in the sub-area "Campground Boulders".

content.description:
This climb follows the obvious left-facing ledge.

 NOTE: The Ledge Fund Boulder is marked "Boulder #2" on the sketch map.
content.location: Walk on the trail until you see a big, blank, overhanging boulder on the right.  Turn right off the trail and you'll be walking through a bunch of smallish boulders.  Ledge Fund faces away from the trail on a larger boulder.

content.description: Start on jugs. Make a pretty big move to gain the lip.
content.location:
Walk along the trail, staying "right" (i.e. straight ahead) at the trail junction,  until you practically walk into this one on your left.

 NOTE: Based on the GoogleEarth maps Jon Guinter posted, (which shows the boulder on the left of the trail, just a little ways beyond where "Tall Boy" & "Stop in French" are located to the right) I have placed this boulder in the Campground Boulders Sub-Area. But this makes it the only route left

of the hiking trail in that sub-area. R Hall, 7/20/20

content.description: Heel hooks, crimps, slopers? What more could you ask for.  This route has it all and then some. Start with your left hand on a side pull on the left face and your right on a side pull in the shallow cave.  Move up and right to a nice half crimp while bumping the left.  Figure out your heel beta and slap up to a small crimp.  Throw around the corner to slopers and work your way to the top of the boulder.
content.location: This problem is located to the right of Tall Boy on the Stop in French Boulder and you can see the large boulder from the trail.

content.description:
Start low on the big flake. Make big moves to reach the finish.

July 2020 Update - The "Flake and Bake" boulder seems to have all 4 sides cleaned (see photos), thus it is assumed there are at least 3 other problems on this boulder. Please make a COMMENT if you have info on these: 1) Location (which face) & description, 2) Grade, 3) Name, 4) FA-er(s) and maybe date of FA.
content.location:
Revised (7/17/20) Directions: Boulder is about 100 +/- feet southwest* of "Tall Boy" / "Stop in French" boulders. ( * i.e. back in the direction of the parking lot, but  roughly, with a 45-degree angle towards the campground.) Or, see the directions in the sub-area "Campground Boulders". 

Original Directions: Follow the trail until it bends left. Turn off and head downhill until you see the campsite. The climb faces the campsite.

content.description: Stand start on the obvious flake with some smears, move up to the jug in the crack and make a couple more mellow moves to the top.
content.location: Walk to the left of the Landmark Boulders and this will be on the boulder right behind it facing downhill.

content.description: This boulder is a great area to warm up and has many options on how to get to the top.
content.protection: Flat landing that can be covered with 2-3 pads.
content.location: This boulder is located to the right from Stop in French and is located downhill towards the campsite.Bob Hall Location Description: Boulder is about 100 +/- feet southwest* of "Tall Boy" / "Stop in French" boulders. ( * i.e. back in the direction of the parking lot, but  roughly, with a 45-degree angle towards the campground.) Or, see the directions in the sub-area "Campground Boulders".

content.description:
This boulder is probably too close to a campsite at the Covered Bridge Campground... unless you're the one camping there. 

  Start sitting on the arete and burl up on edges and slopers to reach the top out.
content.location: Follow the directions for Ledge Fund and keep heading down the hill and to the right until you can see the campsite.  The climb is on the tallest boulder around and faces the camp.

content.description: Start on the lowest positive rail with good feet.  Work your way up to the lip using rails. Top out.
content.location: Walk to the left of the Landmark Boulder, this will be straight ahead of you to the right of no slopes

content.description: A fun friction slab just left of all the hard business. Start on a good foothold just left of Princess Bunnyrabbit, and smear your way onto the lip of that boulder. Keep foot traversing right to the pointy tip and top out.
content.location: Left of Princess Bunnyrabbit, locate a decent foot hold and smear your way to the right across the lip of the boulder.

content.description:
These are the Boulders located on the right of the hiking trail, and run roughly parallel to that trail from just before the trail splits, to just after the trail splits. Many of the existing problems were reported by Jon (and reside in the section "Boulder Loop Bouldering" until they are moved) , including the climb "Stop in French" and its associated boulder(s).

 You are close to the campground, please act and sound accordingly !

NOTE: A Left-to-Right ordering of the boulders is as one looks at the sub-area from the trail towards the actual WMNF campground, which is "opposite" the order you come upon them following the expanded "Getting There" directions below. You can "click" the order icon to get Right-to-Left order if you want to "follow along" with the "getting There" directions.
